comments.author: jbouqui153
comments.body:
Here is our proposal with Manolo as agreed in our last call to be added in "Coherent DWDM pluggable insertion in the router linecard port ('valid for coherent pluggable')" regarding the default parameters topic in pluggables. When I can I will do the Pull Request. Comments are welcome.

"Several coherent pluggables seem to come with a factory default set of parameters (e.g. default channel number, default launched power, default application code id, laser-on, admin-state enabled etc.). This factory default set of parameters varies from manufacturer to manufacturer. This can allow a “plug&play” mode of operation over point-to-point connections (e.g. single wavelength over dark fiber) of course limited to bookended solutions from the same Vendor and same factory default parameters. However, when the optical connection between two pluggables is targeted to run over a DWDM  Open Line System (OLS) network, optical validation & planning step is first required to determine the right target parameters values to be set in the pluggables before interconnecting them to their respective ROADM to avoid to impact any other existing optical channels already up and running in the OLS network.
It is critical for operators to have the same kind of commissioning phase independently of the deployment scenario: point-to-point vs ROADM meshed OLS network. As a consequence, the use of default parameters may be fine but the default set of factory parameters shall be able to be overwritten through router CLI or through Packet PNC to another set of operational default parameters defined by the operator that will change from pluggable to pluggable when deployed over an OLS network. A reset of the coherent pluggable (through router CLI or through Packet PNC) shall always go back to this operator’s default set of operational parameters where, for example, the laser-state shall be ‘Off’ and admin-state ‘disabled’."

comments.author: oscargdd
comments.body:
Thanks for the proposal. Comments below:

1) The ·pre-configuration can come from factory, or operator-driven. E.g. you want to pre-tune your pluggables, etc... It might be useful in some scenarios.  

Text suggestion:

"Coherent pluggables can come with a default set of parameters, either by factory settings or pre-configured by the operator. Pre-configured parameters might include default channel number, default launched power, default application code id, laser-on, admin-state enabled etc.."

2) The fact that it varies is because there is no "enforcement" by any standard right? I also understood that CMIS defines (or maybe recommends...) some defaul parameters. 

Text suggestoin:

"This factory default set of parameters varies from manufacturer to manufacturer, as the standard does not mandate a given set of values, even though some parameters have default values."

3) I would add that the recommendation is that, independently wethere the pluggable comes with a valid pre-configuration or not, it should not inmideatly start transmitting.

Text suggestion:

"In order to avoid unintentionally harming other channels, it is recommended that after a pluggable is connected to the router, by default, the laser is off, and the operator (or the controller) should explictly enable the transceiver."

4) "overwritten through router CLI or through Packet PNC". I think we need to hightlight the the router can have also been preconfigured, and it MUST take prececence over the pluggable. If you modify later, it is a normal case...  Also, I would be agnostic of who configured that (maybe saying management or control is fine) I would suggest:

"shall be overwritten throught the configuration stored in the router, which might have been provided by management or controller means. "


When you make the PR, I make the suggestions there directly, we can continue the discussion here

issues.title: Add use case on maintenance or in-service upgrades at the optical layer
issues.author: oscargdd

issues.title: review from deborah
issues.author: oscargdd
issues.body:
While day 1 (startup) is described, don’t see anything on maintenance or in-service upgrades at the optical layer. A couple of notes (covered in some of the multi-layer RFCs done previously):

-	Avoid disruption in the network – minimal impacts on both optical and packet. Do not want to trigger a network-wide router software update when performing operations on an optical module.
-	Recommend module software – software upgrades/maintenance on the packet level or optical level are not disruptive on the other level.
-	Need to manage properly, including security levels for the different entities.
-	I noted it is said “no protection” – maybe want to soften to say “protection/restoration is for further study”?
-	Measures to include  network wide multi-layer re-optimization strategy to prevent fragmentation and optimal use of capacity (e.g., RFC5557 provides guidance when using a PCE).
-	Measures to protect against network destabilization
-	Measures are needed to support graceful deletion at all layers
-	Fault escalation strategy to coordinate across the layers
-	Mechanisms for aggregating, summarizing, enabling and disabling of inter-layer notifications so as not to overwhelm the controller.

A couple of wording nits:

-	Section 2 “which results in non-optimal and inefficient networking”/s/”which may result in non-optimal and inefficient networking” (marketing/opinion)
-	Section 2 “Placing coherent plugs..can reduce”/s/”Placing coherent plugs..may reduce” (marketing/opinion)
-	Section 5.6 “to avoid proven protection races”/s/”to avoid possible protection races” (proven? May happen if the multi-layers are not managed correctly, a vendor fails to implement proper detection/escalation).

issues.title: discussion points from Gert
issues.author: oscargdd
issues.body:
I keep here for tracking the discussion points

- packet networks are predominantly linked by direct connect fibers and OLS is only a small subset. This draft deals with that subset.
- Optical pluggables exist since >20years, the difference is now that coherent pluggables are way more complex to manage and they are optically interoperable as defined by standards.
- Optical pluggable not only go into routers but also into transponder line-cards of optical systems and OXC.
- Line systems are not controlled by one controller but are typically controlled by vendor specific controllers. Hence at typical IP/MPLS network faces the totality of OLS-systems/subnetworks which involves many O-PSC controllers.
- Optical planning is not always part of the provisioning process. i.e. optical rings can be designed for any-to-any connectivity with 400ZR+ modules. Based on that design, no additional optical planning is needed during the provisioning process as the planning phase has been completed beforehand.
